conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of both particles.
The deceleration phase for particle A starts at t = 2t_0 and ends at t = 4t_0.
The deceleration phase for particle B starts at t = 3t_0 and ends at t = 5t_0.

premise: The deceleration phase for particle A starts at t = 2t_0 and ends at t = 4t_0.
conclusion: For particle A, the acceleration during the deceleration phase is given by the slope of the line segment AB in the velocity-time graph.

premise: The slope of AB for particle A is calculated as (v_AB - v_OA) / (t_AB - t_OA) = (2v_0 - 0) / (4t_0 - 2t_0) = 2v_0 / 2t_0 = v_0 / t_0.
conclusion: The acceleration of particle A during the deceleration phase is v_0 / t_0.

premise: The deceleration phase for particle B starts at t = 3t_0 and ends at t = 5t_0.
conclusion: For particle B, the acceleration during the deceleration phase is given by the slope of the line segment AB in the velocity-time graph.

premise: The slope of AB for particle B is calculated as (v_AB - v_OB) / (t_AB - t_OB) = (2v_0 - 0) / (5t_0 - 3t_0) = 2v_0 / 2t_0 = v_0 / t_0.
conclusion: The acceleration of particle B during the deceleration phase is v_0 / t_0.

premise: The acceleration of particle A during the deceleration phase is v_0 / t_0. The acceleration of particle B during the deceleration phase is v_0 / t_0.
conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases is (v_0 / t_0) / (v_0 / t_0) = 1.
